definition: to look down upon (classical)/to see/to look at (Cantonese)/Mandarin equivalent: 看[kan4]
younger brother/junior male/I (modest word in letter)
unattractive (Cantonese)/Mandarin equivalent: 不好看[bu4 hao3 kan4]

sentences.english: Coz I'll stand beside you through the years.
sentences.chinese: 透過你對眼，你會睇到，我永遠系你身邊。

sentences.english: You shouldn't look down on us, cute sheep.
I learn from the doctor who have to use chinese and western medical for me.
sentences.chinese: 我學今日用中西何合璧幫我睇病嘅嗰個醫生。

sentences.english: Dogleg left, tight entrance, indeed, the fairway is much wider than you see.
sentences.chinese: 左狗腿，入口睇落好窄，不過其實落點好闊。

sentences.english: There are more pictures , if you interesting in them , send you by mail , thank you .
sentences.chinese: 圖片仲有好多的，有興趣的話另外發比您睇。

sentences.english: Just come back from Yokohama. You can found relevant photo in my album.
sentences.chinese: 去完日本返黎，大家可以去我相簿睇相。

sentences.english: Pike gave him a narrow-eyed stare and went back to work.
sentences.chinese: 派克睇視了他一眼，就回去工作了。

sentences.english: And then answer it in Cantonese, Cantonese-speaking users can not read in English.
sentences.chinese: 再用粵語回答啩，睇唔曉粵語嘅網友可以睇英語。

sentences.english: And then answer it in Cantonese, Cantonese-speaking users can not read in English.
sentences.chinese: 再用粵語回答啩，睇唔曉粵語嘅網友可以睇英語。

sentences.english: It seems when you meet her again later, you should teach her English.
sentences.chinese: 睇落打後再遇到佢時，因乖先教佢英語咗。

sentences.english: They teach believers to choose sticks, read tea leaves, palms, or stars;
sentences.chinese: 他們教導信衆去選木條子，看茶葉，睇掌，觀星相等。

definition: so (Cantonese)/Mandarin equivalent: 這樣|这样[zhe4 yang4]
old variant of 慨[kai3]/to sigh (with emotion)
(literary) to wipe away (tears)/to press with one's fingers/to soak
Cantonese particle equivalent to 了[le5] or 過|过[guo4]
to squint/what? (Cantonese)/see also 乜嘢[mie1 ye3]
to be at, in or on (Cantonese)/Mandarin equivalent: 在[zai4]
to connect/to relate to/to tie up/to bind/to be (literary)
to know/to reprimand/to urge/to long for/to tell/to inform
(literary) to wipe away (tears)/to press with one's fingers/to soak
